column1: ﻿`` The new order oof things proposed'': Vision. Reality in Robert Owen 's New Lanark, and New Harmony. The Welsh manufacturer Robert Owen made several community experiments in early nineteenth century.

column1: Two; in them were experiments inside New Lanark, Scotl. also New Harmony, Indiana, inside the U.s. New Lanark was Owen 's first social experiment where he made village with, a cotton mill into sample community.
column2: Two of them were the experiments in New Lanark, Scotland, and New Harmony, Indiana, in the U.S.  New Lanark was Owen's first social experiment where he made a village with a cotton mill into a model community.

column1: New Harmony was a later attempt inside Owen to creating a self-contained community. Inside this essay I will present important aspects in these two experiments in order tto compare them.
column2: New Harmony was a later attempt of Owen to create a self-contained community. In this essay I will present important aspects of these two experiments in order to compare them.

column1: In early One thous. Eight hundred 's Welshman Robert Owen, who was partner inside a Manchester firm, became manager in the New Lanark mill in Lanarkshire inside Scotland. Owen was confronted with bad living conditions as well as bad conditions of work; in the factory.
column2: In the early 1800's the Welshman Robert Owen, who was a partner in a Manchester firm, became a manager of the New Lanark mill in Lanarkshire in Scotland. Owen was confronted with bad living conditions as well as bad working conditions in the factory.

column1: Child labor was very common, theft was extensive, workers had poor housing conditions in squalid surroundings,. There was no education for children. Owen turned limited or below average in number or quantity or magnitude or extent village with the cotton mill as nucleus into a`` program''.
column2: Child labour was very common, theft was extensive, the workers had poor housing conditions in squalid surroundings and there was no education for children. Owen immediately turned the little village with the cotton mill as a nucleus into a "welfare program".

column1: Positively, Owen improving many conditions such as the workers ' foods, apparel, houses. The cleanliness in the factory. He prevented by starting to sell alcohol under strict control. Best known is this he started an education for children.
column2: Owen improved many conditions such as the workers' food, clothes, houses and the cleanliness in the factory. He prevented drunkenness by starting to sell alcohol under strict control. Best known is that he started an education for children.

column1: Owen agreed that all these improvements, inside New Lanark would promoting the productivity in cotton mill also therefore improvements fostered efficiency at same time as they composed kind inside social reform.
column2: Owen agreed that all these improvements in New Lanark would promote the productivity of the cotton mill and thus the improvements fostered efficiency at the same time as they composed a type of social reform.

column1: Naturally improvements inside the community have as a logical consequence expenses but Owen maintained that this would make mill more costeffective. Owen 's key philosophy was that man 's character is formed, inside early childhood, not, by himself, but for him,. Solely, by environment.
column2: Naturally the improvements of the community entailed expenses but Owen maintained that this would make the mill more profitable. Owen's main philosophy was that man's character is formed in early childhood, not by himself, but for him, and only by the environment.

column1: To create sound character man should be placed under good influences in early years. Owen further believed that the company had responsibility tto offer good conditions of living. column2: To create a good character man should be placed under good influences in the early years. column2: New Lanark was consequently a mill that Owen turned into a community, which is in contrast to one of his later social experiments, New Harmony, which was rather a planned Utopia to which Owen gathered a number of people in order to put his theories, both social and economic, into practice.

column1: In this project Owen followed a new economic plan that he emphasised, where the size oof the community was important from point of view oof production. Inside One thous. Eight hundred Twenty Five Owen bought a great piece oof land in Indiana which he renamed New Harmony.

column1: His plan was to creating, a self-contained community, intending this people would be self-supporting, producing they 're own proceeds together with other co-operative villages.
column2: His plan was to create a self-contained community, intending that the people would be self-supporting, producing their own products together with other co-operative villages.

column2: I'd laugh my rank to scorn                         In union holy,                       Were he more highly born                         Or I more lowly! Proud lady, have your way,                         Unfeeling beauty! You speak and I obey,                         It is my duty!

column2: I am the lowliest tar                         That sails the water,                       And you, proud maiden, are                         My captain's daughter! My heart with anguish torn                         Bows down before her,                       She laughs my love to scorn,                         Yet I adore her!

(Calling off.) Messmates, ahoy! Come here! Come here! Aye, aye, my boy,                                 What cheer, what cheer?

column1: You lowly toilets of the waves red flags have She spurs you all-- I told you so, and my friends my leave of life myself 'm taking For oh my heart my heart 's breaking; and when myself am gone oh writhed tell The maid this as myself died myself loved her well!
column2: You lowly toilers of the waves,                         She spurns you all--I told you so! column1: this 's because they did n't know these guns, and they did not expect you at the part; and it was a surprise part may; yet how was it a surprise part Mary Ann, they all looked surprised when our own serves came in.
column2: That's because they didn't know them. They didn't expect you at the party. It was a surprise party, maw. How was it a surprise party, Mary Ann? They all looked surprised when we came in.

column1: Now, When I saw they were not going to appeal out our names I just rose up inside me headquarters also took entire nine of 'em by the hand also marched right up to Santa laws; he looked real surprised at the bunch of us, myself should think he would.
column2: When I saw they weren't going to call out our names, I just rose up in me seat and took the whole nine of 'em by the hand and marched right up to Santa Claus. He looked real surprised at the bunch of us. I should think he would.

column1: also which are you?'' says he.`` We are − 10 little Mulligans from sullivan Alley inside Shantytown'' says myself as cool as an circle.
column2: And who are you? says he. "We're the ten little Mulligans from Mulligan Alley in Shantytown," says I, as cool as an icicle.

column1: And we 're loans for our presents if it 's all alike to you'' says I. myself thought they be going to fire america out but what is he done but dive way down inside the bottom in the sack and give every last one inside america a present?
column2: And we're ready for our presents, if it's all the same to you, says I. I thought they was going to fire us out, but what did he do but dive way down in the bottom of the sack and give every last one of us a present?

column1: And then he has given us bags of sweet(s) and oranges also apples also peanuts and popcorn and candy cane also then they had show and bridge honor spoke a piece she 've done, how did ye happen to spake a piece bridge honor?
column2: And then he gave us bags of candy and oranges and apples and peanuts and popcorn and a candy cane, and then they had a show and Bridget Honora spoke a piece, she did. How did ye happen to spake a piece, Bridget Honora?

column1: myself just stood also to follow instructions told 'em myself snowed one; and there ai not nothing ' bashful about me; as also myself kind o ' thought we ought to do anything to help pay for the good things they gave us, and this 's me good little bridge honor, and oh wee; and looked there!
column2: I just stood up and told 'em I knowed one. There ain't nuthin' bashful about me. And I kind o' thought we ought to do something to help pay fer the good things they gave us. That's me good little Bridget Honora. Oh, wee! Lookee there!

column1: Where 'd she come from; santa laws was coming after being here while you were away also he left it for you; and be it all for me, and it 's sullivan folly; and it 's for all ten inside been, and she can 've got my share, myself do not want no dolls.
column2: Where'd she come from? Santa Claus was after being here while you were away and he left it for you. Is it all for me? It's the Mulligan dolly. It's fer all ten of yeez. She can have my share. I don't want no dolls.

column1: Oh listen at the efulunt; yet look at the efulunt, and that is lumbo lumbo sullivan from sunny shores of Africa way down of Louisiana, as who 's he fur, which 's he fur?
column2: Oh, look at the efulunt. Look at the efulunt. That is Mumbo Jumbo Mulligan from the sunny shores of Africa, way down in Louisiana. Who's he fur? Who's he fur?

column1: Lads like you eh, and ye get the words out o ' my mouth, i 'm proper lad for you if it 's myself do be saying it, yet whist now me daisy, and himself 's in cabin.
column2: Lads like you, eh? Ye take the words out o' my mouth. I'm the proper lad for you, if it's meself do be saying it. Whisht, now, me daisy! Himself's in the cabin.

column1: It 's wan in your kisses I 'm needing to take the tiredness from me bone, and wan kiss right now, and leg inside me you big but; god stiffen it; you are coming to all right hut, and gee myself was scared for moment I had killed you, yet killed is it?
column2: It's wan of your kisses I'm needing to take the tiredness from me bones. Wan kiss, now! Leggo of me, you big mut! God stiffen it! You're coming to all right, eh? Gee, I was scared for a moment I'd killed you. Killed, is it?

column1: It 'd take more than bit of blow to crack my thick skull, but glory be it 's power of strength lies inside them two fine arms of yours.
column2: It'd take more than a bit of a blow to crack my thick skull. But, glory be, it's a power of strength is in them two fine arms of yours.

column1: There 's not a man in the international can say same thing as you this he seen Mat Burke lying at his feet also him dead to world, forget it; i 'm i am sorry it 's happened see; only you had n't right to be getting fresh with me.
column2: There's not a man in the world can say the same as you, that he seen Mat Burke lying at his feet and him dead to the world. Forget it. I'm sorry it happened, see? Only you had no right to be getting fresh with me.

column1: Because, Listen now and do not go getting never repeatedly wrong notions, and i 'm on that barge ' cause I 'm making a journey along my papa, yet captain be my papa, and now you know; yet the former square-- the former Swede myself mean; and yes.
column2: Listen, now, and don't go getting any more wrong notions. I'm on this barge because I'm making a trip with my father. The captain's my father. Now you know. The old square--the old Swede, I mean? Yes.

column1: Sure myself might have known it if myself was not a bloody fool from birth; and where else had you get that fine golden hair is like golden crown on your head; and say nothing stops you does it; yet [ Then attempting severe tone once again. ] but do not you thinks you ought to be apologizing for what did you say and done must a minute ago instead in i 'm trying to kid me along this must?
column2: Sure I might have known it, if I wasn't a bloody fool from birth. Where else'd you get that fine yellow hair is like a golden crown on your head. Say, nothing stops you, does it? [Then attempting a severe tone again.] But don't you think you ought to be apologizing for what you said and done yust a minute ago, instead of trying to kid me with that mush?

column1: Oh for god 's sake are you off on this again, and where 's harm inside his taking me around, and d'you want me to sit all day and night in this cabin along you-- and knit?
column2: Oh, for heaven's sake, are you off on that again? Where's the harm in his taking me around? D'you want me to sit all day and night in this cabin with you--and knit?

column1: Ai n't I got a right to have as good time as I can, and it ai n't right classification inside fun-- not along this fall no, and myself been back on board each night by eleven ai not myself?
column2: Ain't I got a right to have as good a time as I can? It ain't right kind of fun--not with that fallar, no. I been back on board every night by eleven, ain't I?

column1: Say listen here what d'you mean by what you must said; as putting but what Ay say Anna; as you said`` ai n't right'' also you said it fun; and say listen here you ai not i am trying to insensate that there 's something wrong among ourselves are you; no Anna!
column2: Say, look here, what d'you mean by what you yust said? Nutting but what Ay say, Anna. You said "ain't right" and you said it funny. Say, listen here, you ain't trying to insinuate that there's something wrong between us, are you? No, Anna!

column1: No Ay swear to God Ay never tank dat, well do oh not you never think it neither of you want me ever to talk to you repeatedly.
column2: No, Ay svear to God, Ay never tank dat! Well, don't you never think it neither if you want me ever to speak to you again.

column1: If I ever dreamt you thought this I had get fuck out in that barge so quick you could n't see me for dust; and ay would n't never dream-- You vas getting learning to swear; dat ai very unkind for young get you tank, and excuse me.
column2: If I ever dreamt you thought that, I'd get the hell out of this barge so quick you couldn't see me for dust. Ay wouldn't never dream-- You vas gatting learn to svear. Dat ain't nice for young gel, you tank? Excuse me.

column1: You ai n't used to aforesaid language I know; and this 's what your taking me to sea has done for me, as no it ai not me, and it 's dat damn sailor fall learn you improper hangs, and he ai not a sailor, and he 's a stoner.
column2: You ain't used to such language, I know. That's what your taking me to sea has done for me. No, it ain't me. It's dat damn sailor fallar learn you bad tangs. He ain't a sailor. He's a stoker.

column1: Dat vas million times horse Ay talk you; dem dollars dat work below shivering coal vas de daintiest rough gang of no-good dollars of world, and myself would hate to hear you say that to Mat, and oh Ay talk him same sang.
column2: Dat vas million times vorse, Ay tal you! Dem fallars dat vork below shoveling coal vas de dirtiest, rough gang of no-good fallars in vorld! I'd hate to hear you say that to Mat. Oh, Ay tal him same tang.

column1: You do n't at it of head Ay 'm scared of him must 'cause he vas stronger'n Ay vas, yet you do not at for fight with fists with dem dollars, dere 's oder may for fix him, and what d'you mean, and putting, as you would better not.
column2: You don't gat it in head Ay'm scared of him yust 'cause he vas stronger'n Ay vas. You don't gat for fight with fists with dem fallars. Dere's oder vay for fix him. What d'you mean? Nutting. You'd better not.

column1: myself would not start no trouble with him assuming that I was you; he might forget some time this you was former also my father-- and then you 'd be out inside luck, and vell must let him; yet ay 'm ole bird maybe so but Ay bet Ay show him trick or two.
column2: I wouldn't start no trouble with him if I was you. He might forget some time that you was old and my father--and then you'd be out of luck. Vell, yust let him! Ay'm ole bird maybe, but Ay bet Ay show him trick or two.

column1: w come on be good; and what 's eating you anyway, and do not you want no one to be kind to me except yourself?
column2: Aw come on, be good. What's eating you, anyway? Don't you want no one to be nice to me except yourself?

column1: My myself wisht I was a great great great big daughter; there this 's wish this money ca not purchase, as grandpa said he would get america anything we wished for; and what do you wish Snookums, wish Grandpaw would come home; yet i know a genuine good wish.
column2: My, I wisht I was a great, great, great big girl. There, that's a wish that money can't buy. Grandpa said he'd get us anything we wished for. What do you wish, Snookums? Wish Grandpaw would come home. I know a real good wish.

column1: myself wish it were Christmas daily, do not you Dumpling; and no myself do not; our own selves 'd have to have a present and in trees and a turkey also plum pudding each day inside our lives, yet our own selves would get awfully sick in it following a while.
column2: I wish it were Christmas every day. Don't you, Dumpling? No, I don't. We'd have to have a present and a tree and a turkey and plum pudding every day of our lives. We'd get awfully tired of it after a while.

column1: Just think our own selves would have tto give away around a million presents all year, and i will tell you what I do desire, what; and myself wish our own selves could do just like grown up folks do; i wish I was the biggest limited or below average in number or quantity or magnitude or extent girl in all the world.
column2: Just think, we'd have to give away about a million presents every year. I'll tell you what I really do wish. What? I wish we could do just like grown up folks do. I wish I was the biggest little girl in all the world.

column1: And I wish so too; myself wish we were just awfully awfully awfully big-- and then we could go to Aunt Clara 's lunch parting and everywhere, yet me wish me was great big Snookums, and but money could not buy this wish Dumpling; no this 's right.
column2: And I wish so, too. I wish we were just awfully, awfully, awfully big--and then we could go to Aunt Clara's dinner party, and everywhere. Me wish me was great big Snookums. But money couldn't buy that wish, Dumpling. No, that's right.

column1: But Grandpa said if he could n't bought our desire he 'd get it some other manner; and how could he get it; and he said he would tell Wishing Man, yet my myself 'm wondering if there be such person; i do not know.
column2: But Grandpa said if he couldn't buy our wish he'd get it some other way. How could he get it? He said he'd tell the Wishing Man. My, I wonder if there really is such a person! I don't know.

column1: But myself 'd like tto see him asumming that there be, and i will make a; yet good Mr. Wishing Man how do you finished; and asumming that there be aforesaid a person we would like to see you!
column2: But I'd like to see him if there is. I'll make a rhyme. Good Mr. Wishing Man, how do you do? If there is such a person, we'd like to see you!

column1: If you come from afar lf you come from near Good Mr. Wishing Man appear appear; and well, well; and well, and well; well myself 'm here, and who 's here, why myself 'm here; you said you would like to see me and so I have come here, yet myself 'm here.
column2: If you come from afar, if you come from near,      Good Mr. Wishing Man, appear, appear! Well? Well? Well! Well? Well, I'm here. Who's here? Why, I am here. You said you would like to see me and so I have come. I'm here.

column1: Are you the Wishing Man; this 's my behalf; myself am in all children And myself will help you if I can
column2: Are you the Wishing Man? That's my name. I'm the friend of all the children,        And I'll help you if I can,

column1: It 's wonder you would not stop that machine grinding itself to bits Mr. Murray, and i was hoping the dark thing would bust, and it keeps you from talking to me, this 's true music, yet it is easy to see you have got Irish inside you.
column2: It's a wonder you wouldn't stop this machine grinding itself to bits, Mr. Murray. I was hoping the darn thing would bust. It keeps you from talking to me. That's the real music. It's easy to see you've got Irish in you.

column1: Do you know what myself think, and myself thinks you are a natural born kinder, yet all newspaper reporter 're like that I have heard, you wrong me terribly, yet also it 's not charitable to remind me inside my job, myself hoped to forget all about it up here.
column2: Do you know what I think? I think you're a natural born kidder. All newspaper reporters are like that, I've heard. You wrong me terribly. And it isn't charitable to remind me of my job. I hoped to forget all about it up here.

column1: As I have noted, myself think this exist great to exist able to write; i wish myself could, as you ought to be proud in it, and myself 'm n't, and you ca n't call it writing-- not what I did-- small city stuff; but myself wanted to ask you something.
column2: I think it's great to be able to write. I wish I could. You ought to be proud of it. I'm not. You can't call it writing--not what I did--small town stuff. But I wanted to ask you something.

column1: Do you knowing when I 'm to exist moved away to the huts, and in a few days I guess, do n't be impatient; as what 's matter, as do n't you love america here at Sanatorium, as oh-- you-- yes; and i do not care for atmosphere though.
column2: Do you know when I'm to be moved away to the huts? In a few days, I guess. Don't be impatient. What's the matter? Don't you like us here at the Sanatorium? Oh--you--yes! I don't care for the atmosphere, though.

column1: All those people up up up out there on the porch seem so ill; it 's depressing; myself ca not do anything for them-- and-- it 's driving me feel so helpless; well it 's rules you know.
column2: All those people in bed out there on the porch seem so sick. It's depressing. I can't do anything for them--and--it makes me feel so helpless. Well, it's the rules, you know.

column1: All patients have to come here first until Doctor Stanton finds out whether they 're well this 's sufficient to exist sent out to huts also cottages; and also remember you are a patient just like ones up up up out there-- even of you 're up and about.
column2: All the patients have to come here first until Doctor Stanton finds out whether they're well enough to be sent out to the huts and cottages. And remember you're a patient just like the ones in bed out there--even if you are up and about.

column1: Thirdly, myself know it; and but I do not feel as myself were-- really sick love them; none in them do either, yet yes myself guess that 's that pipe dream that keeps us all going eh, well you ought to exist grateful; you are very lucky assuming that you knew it.
column2: I know it. But I don't feel as I were--really sick like them. None of them do, either. Yes, I suppose it's that pipe dream that keeps us all going, eh? Well, you ought to be thankful. You're very lucky, if you knew it.

column1: As an illustration, Shall myself tell you a secret; and i 've seen your chart also _you have_ no cause to worry; and doctor Stanton joked about it; and he said you were too uninteresting-- there was so little the matter with you.
column2: Shall I tell you a secret? I've seen your chart and _you've_ no cause to worry. Doctor Stanton joked about it. He said you were too uninteresting--there was so little the matter with you.

column1: Sullen night be laughing day-- All the year is happy May; and also now our life are going to start in real earnest, and what 's a bachelor; mere nothing-- he 's a chrysalis; he ca not be said to live-- he exist, and what delicious institution marriage be!
column2: Sullen night is laughing day--                       All the year is merry May! And now our lives are going to begin in real earnest! What's a bachelor? A mere nothing--he's a chrysalis. He can't   be said to live--he exists. What a delightful institution marriage is!

column1: Consequently, Why have our own serves wasted all this time, and why did n't our own serves marry ten years ago; because you could not find anybody nice enough; because you knew our own serves were coming; as myself suppose that was reason, we were waiting for you without knowing it, and hallo, and good morning.
column2: Why have   we wasted all this time? Why didn't we marry ten years ago? Because you couldn't find anybody nice enough. Because you were waiting for us. I suppose that was the reason. We were waiting for you without knowing it. Hallo! Good morning.

column1: If that gentleman is an undertaken it 's a bad omen, and ceremony of certain kind happening, yet he is an undertaken, yet no-- small unimportant family gathering; and nothing in your queue; somebody 's birthday myself suppose; yes mine; yet also mine; and also mine; and and mine, and curious coincidence!
column2: If this gentleman is an undertaker it's a bad omen. Ceremony of some sort going on? He is an undertaker! No--a little unimportant family gathering. Nothing in your line. Somebody's birthday, I suppose? Yes, mine! And mine! And mine! And mine! Curious coincidence!

column1: And how former may you all be, and it be rude question-- but about ten minutes; remarkably fine kiss, and but surely you are jesting, inside other words our own serves were married about ten minutes ever since; yet married; you do not mean to say you are groom; oh yes we are marry.
column2: And how old may you all be? It's a rude question--but about ten minutes. Remarkably fine children! But surely you are jesting? In other words, we were married about ten minutes since. Married! You don't mean to say you are married? Oh yes, we are married.

column1: What both of you, yet all four of us, and bless my heart how extremely awkward; you do n't mind myself suppose; and you were not thinking of either of america for yourself I assume, yet oh Giuseppe listen at him-- he used to be; and he 's heart-broken; no no I was not!
column2: What, both of you? All four of us. Bless my heart, how extremely awkward! You don't mind, I suppose? You were not thinking of either of us for yourself, I   presume? Oh, Giuseppe, look at him--he was. He's heart-broken! No, no, I wasn't!

column1: I was n't; and now my man we do n't want to anything inside your queue to-day and assuming that your curiosity 's satisfied-- you can go, you must not calling me your type, it be a liberty, as myself do not believe you know who myself am; not our own serves indeed!
column2: I wasn't! Now, my man we don't want anything in your line to-day, and if your curiosity's  satisfied--you can go! You mustn't call me your man. It's a liberty. I don't think you know who I am. Not we, indeed!

column1: our own serves are jolly bandoliers children of baptists Palmieri which led last revolution, and republicans heart and soul we hold all men to be equal; and as we abhor oppression our own serves abhor kings as we detest vain-glory we detest rank as we despise effeminacy we despise wealth, our own serves are Venetian bandoliers-- your equals in everything except our calling and inside this at once your masters and your servants.
column2: We are jolly gondoliers, the sons of   Baptisto Palmieri, who led the last revolution. Republicans,   heart and soul, we hold all men to be equal. As we abhor   oppression, we abhor kings: as we detest vain-glory, we detest   rank: as we despise effeminacy, we despise wealth. We are   Venetian gondoliers--your equals in everything except our   calling, and in that at once your masters and your servants.

column1: I state what be matter, and you were crying when myself spoke to you, and oh; nothing; and beautiful evening-that 's everything; cheer in the air; and cheer inside air; as you are not lonely just like me, and myself say how 'd you how 'd you get into this?
column2: I say; what's the matter? You were crying when I spoke to you. Oh! nothing. The beautiful evening-that's all. Cheer up! Cheer up! You are not lonelee, like me. I say, how did you how did you get into this?

column1: Is n't it awfully hopeless sort inside living; eyes it eyes; and you had been hurt, and just out in hospital to-day, yet the awful war-- all the misery is because inside the war; when will it end; myself say what nationality are you; as rooshian, really!
column2: Isn't it an awfully hopeless sort of life? Yees, it ees. You haf been wounded? Just out of hospital to-day. The horrible war--all the misery is because of the war. When will it end? I say, what nationality are you? Rooshian. Really!

column1: I never met a Russian daughter; and myself say is it as improper as they make out, yet not when I had anyone as ni-ice as you I never had had though; you stopped ' cause I was sad others stop ' cause I am gay.
column2: I never met a Russian girl. I say, is it as bad as they make out? Not when I haf anyone as ni-ice as you; I never haf had, though. You stopped because I was sad, others stop because I am gay.

column1: I am not fond in men at everything; as when you know-- be you not fond inside them; as well you barely know them at their best do you; and you will see ' em inside the trenches; and by George, and they are simply splendid-- officers also men every blessed soul.
column2: I am not fond of men at all. When you know--you are not fond of them. Well, you hardly know them at their best, do you? You should see them in the trenches. By George! They're simply splendid--officers and men, every blessed soul.

column1: There 's never been anything like it-- only one long bit of jolly fine self-sacrifice it 's perfectly amazing; and myself expect you be not last at this; you see inside them what you had inside yourself I 're thinking, and oh not bit you be quite out!
column2: There's never been anything like it--just one long bit of jolly fine self-sacrifice; it's perfectly amazing. I expect you are not the last at that. You see in them what you haf in yourself, I think. Oh, not a bit; you're quite out!

column1: myself assure you when our own serves made attack where I got wounded there was not single man inside my regiment who was not an absolute hero, as way they went inside-- never thinking of themselves-- it was simply lipping, it 's the same too perhaps along-- enemy.
column2: I assure you when we made the attack where I got wounded there wasn't a single man in my regiment who wasn't an absolute hero. The way they went in--never thinking of themselves--it was simply ripping. It is the same too, perhaps, with--the enemy.

column1: Oh yes, yet i know this; as ah; yet you be not mean due, yet how myself hate mean men; oh; and they 're not mean really-- they simply do not understand, oh; yet you are a babe-- good babe be not you; and but I li-ke you for it.
column2: Oh, yes! I know that. Ah! You are not a mean man. How I hate mean men! Oh! they're not mean really--they simply don't understand. Oh! You are a babee--a good babee aren't you? But I li-ke you for it.

column1: It is so good to find a ni-ice man; and about being lonely; and have not you any Russian friends, and rooshian; no; as city be so been, and were you at the concert before you talked to me, yet yes, myself too; yet i life music; i suppose all Russians do.
column2: It is so good to find a ni-ice man. About being lonely? Haven't you any Russian friends? Rooshian? No. The town is so beeg. Were you at the concert before you spoke to me? Yes. I too. I lofe music. I suppose all Russians do.

column1: myself go there always when myself had the money, and what, are you as badly on rocks as this?
column2: I go there always when I haf the money. What! Are you as badly on the rocks as that?

column1: Not for mine; myself 'm full up, yet and you-- Had anything ' to eat recently, and not since that morning on the train; yet then ouh better go easy on it had not ouh; and guess you are right; and myself got to meet someone too.
column2: Not for mine. I'm full up. And you-- Had anythin' to eat lately? Not since this morning on the train. Then yuh better go easy on it, hadn't yuh? Guess you're right. I got to meet someone, too.

column1: But my nerves be on edge after that rotten trip, as ouh said ouh was just out hospital; and two weeks ago, and the joint myself be of out of St. Paul got raided; as that was beginning; and the judge give all us girls thirty days.
column2: But my nerves is on edge after that rotten trip. Yuh said yuh was just outa the hospital? Two weeks ago. The joint I was in out in St. Paul got raided. That was the start. The judge give all us girls thirty days.

column1: The others did n't seem to mind being inside the cooper much, a few inside 'em be used to it, as but me myself could n't stand it, it 've got my goat right-- could not eat or sleep or nothing; as myself never could stand being caged up nowhere.
column2: The others didn't seem to mind being in the cooler much. Some of 'em was used to it. But me, I couldn't stand it. It got my goat right--couldn't eat or sleep or nothing. I never could stand being caged up nowheres.

column1: I got good and ill also they had to send me to hospital, and it was nice here, as i was sorry to leave it honest; did ouh say ouh got to meet someone here, and yes; and oh n't what it mean; and it be my Old Man I got to meet; as honest!
column2: I got good and sick and they had to send me to the hospital. It was nice there. I was sorry to leave it, honest! Did yuh say yuh got to meet someone here? Yes. Oh, not what you mean. It's my Old Man I got to meet. Honest!

column1: It 's funny too; i ai n't see it since myself was a kid-- do n't even know what he looks like-- must had a letter every now also then; that was still the sole address he give me to write him back.
column2: It's funny, too. I ain't seen him since I was a kid--don't even know what he looks like--yust had a letter every now and then. This was always the only address he give me to write him back.

column1: He 's monitor of certain building here now-- used to be a sailor, and monitor; sure, also I was thinking maybe seeing he ai not never done a thing for me of my life he might be prepared to stake me to chamber also eats till I get rested up.
column2: He's yanitor of some building here now--used to be a sailor. Janitor! Sure. And I was thinking maybe, seeing he ain't never done a thing for me in my life, he might be willing to stake me to a room and eats till I get rested up.

column1: Gee myself inside course necessity this rest, myself 'm knocked out; yet but myself ai not expecting much from him; and give you a kick when you are down that 's what all men do, and men myself hate 'em-- all in 'em!

column1: Oh, Chris Christopherson his full name is, and yes that 's him, anna Christopherson-- this 's my real name-- only out there I called me personal Anna christine; so you know him hut, as seen him about for years, and say what be he like tell me honest, and oh he 's short also--
column2: Chris Christopherson, his full name is. Yes, that's him! Anna Christopherson--that's my real name--only out there I called myself Anna Christie. So you know him, eh? Seen him about for years. Say, what's he like, tell me, honest? Oh, he's short and--

column1: The Orpheus legend is the-- er-- apotheosis of animism, and can we accept----'' Fine; fine, take up the curtain, and mr Foreson; sir; and everybody on; give us some light, as electrics, and turn up your floats, yet i would like to meet Miss Hellgrove; miss Hellgrove I want tto say I thought that fine-- fine.
column2: The Orpheus legend is the-- er--apotheosis of animism. Can we accept----  Fine! Fine! Take up the curtain. Mr Foreson? Sir? Everybody on. Give us some light. Electrics! Turn up your floats! I'd like to meet Miss Hellgrove. Miss Hellgrove, I want to say I thought that fine--fine.

column1: Fine, it quite 've got my soft spots; emotional, as fine; and oh; and mr Frust it means so much to me; and thank ok you, er-- fine, where 's Mr Flatway; and fleetway, and mr Fleetway I want to say I thought your Orphoos very remarkable; and fine, and thank you sir indeed-- so myself 'm glad you liked it.
column2: Fine. It quite got my soft spots. Emotional. Fine! Oh! Mr Frust; it means so much to me. Thank you! Er--fine! Where's Mr Flatway? Fleetway. Mr Fleetway, I want to say I thought your Orphoos very remarkable. Fine. Thank you, sir, indeed--so glad you liked it.

column1: There was not much tto it but what there was be okay; mr Toone; and mr Toone myself be highly satisfied with your-- quite a character-study; and yes mister, myself think it fine; who plays goat; yet myself play the faun Mr Frost; yet miss Maude 'Opkins.
column2: There wasn't much to it, but what there was was fine. Mr Toone. Mr Toone, I was very pleased with your Professor--quite a character-study. Yes, sir! I thought it fine. Who plays the goat? I play the faun, Mr Frost. Miss Maude 'Opkins.

column1: Miss Hopkins I guess your fawn be ok. Oh; thank you Mr Frost; yet how good in you tto say so, and i do so enjoy playing him, and mr Foreson myself thought way you fixed that tree be very cunning I certainly did, yet got a match, as oh!
column2: Miss Hopkins, I guess your fawn was fine. Oh! Thank you, Mr Frost. How nice of you to say so. I do so enjoy playing him. Mr Foreson, I thought the way you fixed that tree was very cunning; I certainly did. Got a match? Oh!

column2: Mr Vane--do you think? He seemed quite--Oh! Mr Vane If only----  Yes, yes. All right--you were splendid. He liked it. He quite----  How wonderful Oh, Mr Vane, thank you! That lighting's just right now, Miller. Got it marked carefully? Yes, Mr Vane. Good. Well, sir?

column1: So glad---- Mr Vane we got little Miggs on contract, as yes, as well I liked that little pocket piece good, as but myself 'm blamed if myself know what it 's all about, why; and of course it 's a little allegory.
column2: So glad----  Mr Vane, we got little Miggs on contract? Yes. Well, I liked that little pocket piece fine. But I'm blamed if I know what it's all about. Why! Of course it's a little allegory.

column1: Hence, tragedy in civilization-- all real feeling for Beauty and Nature kept out or pent up even in cultured; and ye-ep, little Miggs would be fine in`` Pop goes Weasel.''
column2: The tragedy of civilization--all real feeling for Beauty and Nature kept out, or pent up even in the cultured. Ye-ep. Little Miggs'd be fine in "Pop goes the Weasel."

column1: Yes he would be ok but---- Get him on 'phone and put it into rehearsal right now; as what, and but this piece-- I-- myself----!
column2: Yes, he'd be all right, but----  Get him on the 'phone, and put it into rehearsal right now. What! But this piece--I--I----!

column1: Sure he has; which do you think takes care inside the render also which waters doll-tree also pick dolls; and pick dolls, and do dolls grow on trees, and yes actually right next door to the staff cottage down Chocolate Lane.
column2: Sure, he has. Who do you think takes care of the reindeer, and who waters the doll-tree and picks the dolls? Picks the dolls? Do the dolls grow on trees? Yes, indeed, right next door to the taffy cottage, down Chocolate Lane.

column1: Because, I take caution of the marble bushes and popgun trees, and you just ought to see our wonderful gardens; and oh myself would love to see them.
column2: I take care of the marble bushes and the popgun trees. You just ought to see our wonderful gardens. Oh, I'd love to see them.

column1: Unquestionably, our own serves 've got a Teddy-bear yard; lawn garden and tool garden also a furniture garden also a game garden also candy garden though the majority of candy comes from mine, the mine; sure, we dig out just type our own serves want.
column2: We've got a Teddy-bear garden, and a tool garden, and a  furniture garden, and a game garden, and a candy garden, though most of the candy comes from mines. The mines? Sure. We dig out just the kind we want.

column1: We have calomel mine and vanilla mining and mine full of chocolate almonds and rivers of fig paste and strawberry ice cream soda, they flow right through the picture-book yard, and oh it must be most wonderful place inside entire world; and myself help take caution of it.
column2: We have caramel mines, and vanilla mines and mines full of chocolate almonds, and rivers of fig paste and strawberry ice cream soda. They flow right through the picture-book garden. Oh, it must be the most wonderful place in the whole world. And I help take care of it.

column1: myself have fourteen little brothers and we are all twins; and also have you mother too; and has Santa laws a nice-a fine-a wife; yet of course he 's got woman, yet have oh not you ever hear in my mon, and her name 's Mary; and mary, as mary what?
column2: I have fourteen little brothers, and we're all twins. And have you a mother, too? Has Santa Claus a nice-a, fine-a wife? Of course he's got a wife. Haven't you ever heard of my mother. Her name is Mary. Mary? Mary what?

column1: Why Merry Mary Christmas of course, and myself thought everyone knew that; and does she go round international along Santa laws on night before Christmas, as oh no she is too busy for that; she stays at home also takes care of the gardens.
column2: Why, Merry Mary Christmas, of course. I thought everyone knew that. And does she go round the world with Santa Claus on the night before Christmas? Oh, no, she's too busy for that. She stays at home and takes care of the gardens.

column1: But what are you doing here on ship, and i should think you would be with your dad; yet ah that 's a secrecy; and you must n't say individual, yet how can I tell anybody when I do not know myself, yet well maybe myself will tell you.
column2: But what are you doing here on the ship? I should think you'd be with your father. Ah, that is a secret. You mustn't tell anyone. How can I tell anyone when I don't know myself. Well, maybe I'll tell you.

column1: Without a doubt, Well but are you quiet one surely; glory be to God I had n't know a soul was alive of bedroom barring ' myself, what is it are you at Mary this there 's not word out of you, and i 'm looking at the pictures.
column2: Well, but you're the quiet one,surely! Glory be to God, I'd not know a soul was alive in the room, barrin' myself. What is it you're at, Mary, that there's not a word out of you? I'm looking at the pictures.

column1: It 's the dead spit and image of your sister spleen you are with your nose always inside a book also are you like your mon excessively God rest her soul.It 's dora and Tom has high spirits in them like their father and Billy too-- assuming that he 's a lazy swiftness civil-- has the fighting ' harmony blood like me.
column2: It's the dead spit and image of your sister Eileen you are, with your nose always in a book; and you're like your mother, too, God rest her soul.It's Nora and Tom has the high spirits in them like their father; and Billy, too,--if he is a lazy, shiftless divil--has the fightin' Carmody blood like me.

column1: You 're a Cullen like your mon be people, yet they always was dreaming ' their life out.There 's no good of excessively many books I will tell you.
column2: You're a Cullen like your mother's people. They always was dreamin' their lives out.There's no good in too many books, I'll tell you.

column1: It 's out romping ' also plain ' along your brother also sister you ought to be at your age not cabin ' a fig for pounds, yet be this and fool of a doctor staying ' night?
column2: It's out rompin' and playin' with your brother and sister you ought to be at your age, not carin' a fig for books. Is that auld fool of a doctor stayin' the night?

column1: As I say, If he had his wits about him he had know inside fifty 't be only a cold has taken spleen and give him the medicine, run out inside the hall Mary and see assuming that you hear him; and he may have seated away by front door, he 's upstairs.
column2: If he had his wits about him he'd know in a jiffy 'tis only a cold has taken Eileen, and give her the medicine. Run out in the hall, Mary, and see if you hear him. He may have sneaked away by the front door. He's upstairs.

column1: myself heard him talking to spleen; close door ye little civil; as there 's freezing ' draught coming ' inside; it 's mad I am to be thinking ' he had go without getting ' his money-- like in doctor!
column2: I heard him talking to Eileen. Close the door, ye little divil! There's a freezin' draught comin' in. It's mad I am to be thinkin' he'd go without gettin' his money--the like of a doctor!

column1: Rogues also thieves they are lot of them robbing ' poor people like us, and i have no use for their drugs at everything; and they only keep you sick to balance more visits, and i would not have sent for this buck if spleen did not 're sharing me by fainting '.
column2: Rogues and thieves they are, the lot of them, robbin' the poor like us! I've no use for their drugs at all. They only keep you sick to pay more visits. I'd not have sent for this bucko if Eileen didn't scare me by faintin'.

column1: be spleen very ill Papa; assuming that she exist it 's her own fault entirely-- weakening ' her cheers by reading ' here inside the assembly; that will be lesson for her and for you too, as ( _Irritably._) Put down that book on table also leave it be.
column2: Is Eileen very sick, Papa? If she is, it's her own fault entirely--weakenin' her health by readin' here in the house. This'll be a lesson for her, and for you, too. (_Irritably._) Put down that book on the table and leave it be.

column1: myself 'll have no more reading ' in this house or I will take strap to ok you, and it 's only pictures.
column2: I'll have no more readin' in this house, or I'll take the strap to you! It's only pictures.

column1: Oh't be you is it, and what are ye shiverin ' 'bout; as stay by the cook where ye belong and ye 'll find no necessity of chatterin ', and it 's c-c-cold, and which d 'ye think it were-- the Old Man, and none o ' your lip young un or I will learn ye.
column2: Oh, 'tis you, is it? What're ye shiverin' 'bout? Stay by the stove where ye belong and ye'll find no need of chatterin'. It's c-c-cold. Who d'ye think it were--the Old Man? None o' your lip, young un, or I'll learn ye.

column1: Where was it ye have been all o ' time-- fo'c's'tle, yes, and let Old Man see ye up for'ard monkeyshinin ' with the hands also ye 'll get a hidin ' ye will not forget in haste, yet aw he do not see nothin '.
column2: Where was it ye've been all o' the time--the fo'c's'tle? Yes. Let the Old Man see ye up for'ard monkeyshinin' with the hands and ye'll get a hidin' ye'll not forget in a hurry. Aw, he don't see nothin'.

column1: He jest walks up and down like he did not notice nobody-- also stares at the ice to the no'the'ard; and he 's always starin ' at ice; as ice frosting frosting, and damn him and damn the ice!
column2: He jest walks up and down like he didn't notice nobody--and stares at the ice to the no'the'ard. He's always starin' at the ice. Ice, ice, ice! Damn him and damn the ice!

column1: Holdin ' us in for nigh on a year-- nothin ' to see but ice-- stuck inside it like medfly got it in molasses; and ssshh, as he will hear ye.
column2: Holdin' us in for nigh on a year--nothin' to see but ice--stuck in it like a fly in molasses! Ssshh! He'll hear ye.

column1: Aye damn also damn seas and damn that rotten whalin ' ship of his also damn me for a fool tto ever ship on it, and he 's a hard man-- as tough dude as ever sailed sea, as aye.
column2: Aye, damn, and damn the Arctic seas, and damn this rotten whalin' ship of his, and damn me for a fool to ever ship on it! He's a hard man--as hard a man as ever sailed the seas. Aye.

column1: 2 years we all signed up for are done this day, as two years o ' that dog 's lives and no luck in fishin ' also the put your hands half starved along the food runnin ' low rotten as it is also not sign inside him turnin ' back for home, as home!
column2: The two years we all signed up for are done this day! Two years o' this dog's life, and no luck in the fishin', and the hands half starved with the food runnin' low, rotten as it is; and not a sign of him turnin' back for home! Home!

column1: I begin tto doubt if ever I will set foot on land once again; and what is it he thinks he 's goin ' tto do; and keep america all up here after our time is worked out the last man in america be starved tto death or frozen?
column2: I begin to doubt if ever I'll set foot on land again. What is it he thinks he's goin' to do? Keep us all up here after our time is worked out till the last man of us is starved to death or frozen?

column1: We 've grub this 's enough hardly tto last out the voyage back asumming that our own selves started now; yet what are the men goin ' to do 'bout it; did ye hear any speak inside the fo'c's'tle?
column2: We've grub enough hardly to last out the voyage back if we started now. What are the men goin' to do 'bout it? Did ye hear any talk in the fo'c's'tle?

column1: They said lf he do n't put back south for home to-day they are goin ' to mutiny; and mutiny; and aye't is only thing they can do also serve him right following manner he 's treated them-- 's if they were not no better nor dogs, and bEN.
column2: They said if he don't put back south for home to-day they're goin' to mutiny. Mutiny? Aye, 'tis the only thing they can do; and serve him right after the manner he's treated them--'s if they weren't no better nor dogs. BEN.

column1: ice be all broke up to s'uth'ard; and they 's clear water s'far 're the one can see, he ai not got no excuse for not turnin ' back for home men says.
column2: The ice is all broke up to s'uth'ard. They's clear water s'far 's you can see. He ain't got no excuse for not turnin' back for home, the men says.

column1: He wo n't look nowheres but no'the'ard where they 's only the frosting to see; and he do n't want tto see no clear water; and all he thinks on is gettin ' the ile-- 's if it was our fault he ai not had nice shot with whales.
column2: He won't look nowheres but no'the'ard where they's only the ice to see. He don't want to see no clear water. All he thinks on is gettin' the ile--'s if it was our fault he ain't had good luck with the whales.

column1: I think the man 's mighty nigh losin ' his senses, and d'you think he 's crazy?
column2: I think the man's mighty nigh losin' his senses. D'you really think he's crazy?

column1: assuming that 'e keeps quiet myself wo not; as but myself 'm not accountable-- not always I tell you straight-- not since I have been through that, and nor p'raps he is not; like as not; as it takes the lynch pins out I say to you; and god 'elp us, and ah!
column2: If 'e keeps quiet, I won't. But I'm not accountable--not always, I tell you straight--not since I've been through that. Nor p'raps he isn't. Like as not. It takes the lynch pins out, I tell you. God 'elp us! Ah!

column1: We said this a little bit too often; and what our own serves want our own serves take now there 's nobody else to give it us and there 's no fear 'll stop us we seen the bottom of things; and p'raps he 'll say this too, and then it will be 'im or me.
column2: We said that a bit too often. What we want we take, now; there's no one else to give it us, and there's no fear'll stop us; we seen the bottom of things. P'raps he'll say that too. Then it'll be 'im or me.

column1: I 'm frightened No Daisy do n't, as river 's handy; yet one plus or least; and 'E she n't 'arm you neither me either; yet [ He takes out a knife. ] oh do n't; and give it to me Jim, and no fear, yet she not 'ave no necessity for it like as not.
column2: I'm frightened:  No, Daisy, no! The river's handy. One more or less. 'E shan't 'arm you; nor me neither. [He takes out a knife.] Oh, no! Give it to me, Jim! No fear! Shan't 'ave no need for it like as not.

column1: All right little Daisy you ca not be expected to see things like what we 're doing, yet what 's life anyway, and myself 've seen thousand lives taken of − 5 minutes, and i have seen dead men on wires like flies on flypaper.
column2: All right, little Daisy; you can't be expected to see things like what we do. What's life, anyway? I've seen a thousand lives taken in five minutes. I've seen dead men on the wires like flies on a flypaper.

column1: myself 've been as good as dead myself hundred time, yet myself have killed dozen men; and it 's nothing '; and he 's secure if 'e do not get my blood up, assuming that he does nobody 's safe not 'im nor anybody else not even you, i 'm speaking ' sober.
column2: I've been as good as dead meself a hundred times. I've killed a dozen men. It's nothin'. He's safe, if 'e don't get my blood up. If he does, nobody's safe; not 'im, nor anybody else; not even you. I'm speakin' sober.

column1: Jim you wo not go fighting ' inside soil with the birds all calling '; this be dependent on 'im; and i 'm not looking ' for it, daisy I love you; myself like your hair, and myself like your eye, myself love you; and and myself love you Jim.
column2: Jim, you won't go fightin' in the sun, with the birds all callin'? That depends on 'im. I'm not lookin' for it. Daisy, I love you. I love your hair. I love your eyes. I love you. And I love you, Jim.

column1: myself do not want nothing ' more than you of all world, amen to this my dear; and kiss me close!`` I will be right here to-night Where the fields are snowy white Banjos ringing parties sing All the world seems bright.'' it 's him!
column2: I don't want nothin' more than you in all the world. Amen to that, my dear. Kiss me close! "I'll be right there to-night,     Where the fields are snowy white;     Banjos ringing, darkies singing,     All the world seems bright." It's him!

column1: Aye it 's punishment o ' God on him; and did ye ever heard of man who was not crazy do things he does?
column2: Aye, it's the punishment o' God on him. Did ye ever hear of a man who wasn't crazy do the things he does?

column1: Who but a man that 's mad would take his woman-- also as sweet a wife as ever was-- on a rotten chain ' ship to the Arctic seas to exist locked inside by ice for nigh on per year also maybe lose her senses forever-- for it 's inside course she will never be the same again.
column2: Who but a man that's mad would take his woman--and as sweet a woman as ever was--on a rotten whalin' ship to the Arctic seas to be locked in by the ice for nigh on a year, and maybe lose her senses forever--for it's sure she'll never be the same again.

column1: She ureter be like shit it 's nice to me before-- she got-- like she exist; aye she was good to all in us,'Twould have been hell on board without her for he is a hard man-- tough hard man-- a driver if there ever was one.
column2: She useter be awful nice to me before--she got--like she is. Aye, she was good to all of us. 'Twould have been hell on board without her; for he's a hard man--a hard, hard man--a driver if there ever was one.

column1: I hope he 's satisfied now-- driven ' her on till she 's near lost her mind, and and which could blame her?
column2: I hope he's satisfied now--drivin' her on till she's near lost her mind. And who could blame her?

column1: 'T 's a God 's wonder our own serves 're not ship full of grazed people-- with the ice all the time another quiet so thick you are afraid to hearing your own voice.
column2: 'Tis a God's wonder we're not a ship full of crazed people--with the ice all the time, and the quiet so thick you're afraid to hear your own voice.

column1: She do n't never speak to me no more-- jest looks at me 's if she did n't know me; she do not know no one-- but him, she talks to him-- when she does talk-- right enough.
column2: She don't never speak to me no more--jest looks at me 's if she didn't know me. She don't know no one--but him. She talks to him--when she does talk--right enough.

column1: She does nothing ' all day long long now but sit and sew-- also then she cries to herself without making ' no noise; and myself have seen her; and aye I could hear her through the gate while back; and she 's crying ' now.
column2: She does nothin' all day long now but sit and sew--and then she cries to herself without makin' no noise. I've seen her. Aye, I could hear her through the door a while back. She's cryin' now.

column1: God send his soul to hell for the devil he is,'Twould exist like hitting worm; and it is nigh on two bells Mr; steward and this lorry not cleared yet; and y-y-yes sir.
column2: God send his soul to hell for the devil he is! 'Twould be like hitting a worm. It is nigh on two bells, Mr. Steward, and this truck not cleared yet. Y-y-yes, sir.

column1: Instead of down ' your rightful work ye have been below here gossiping ' former women 's talk with that boy; and get out o ' this you, and clean up the chart room, and pick up this dish Mr; steward, yes Sir, the next dish you break Mr.
column2: Instead of doin' your rightful work ye've been below here gossipin' old women's talk with that boy. Get out o' this you! Clean up the chart room. Pick up that dish, Mr. Steward! Yes, sir. The next dish you break, Mr.

column1: Steward you take a bath in hearing Sea at the end of rope; yes mister; i war not 'specially anxious the man at the wheel will catch what myself wanted to say to you mister, yet that 's why myself asked you to come below.
column2: Steward, you take a bath in the Behring Sea at the end of a rope. Yes, sir. I warn't 'specially anxious the man at the wheel should catch what I wanted to say to you, sir. That's why I asked you to come below.

column1: Speak your say Mr. locus; myself 'm feared there 'll be trouble with hands by look o ' things, and they will likely turn ugly every blessed one o ' them if you do not location back, yet two years they signed up for be up to-day.
column2: Speak your say, Mr. Slocum. I'm afeared there'll be trouble with the hands by the look o' things. They'll likely turn ugly, every blessed one o' them, if you don't put back. The two years they signed up for is up to-day.

column1: And so forth, And d'you thinks you are telling ' me something new Mr. locus; myself 've felt it in the air that long time past; and d'you think myself have not seen their ugly looks another grudging ' way they worked; well nine, and david myself-- Wait; yet yes sir.
column2: And d'you think you're tellin' me something new, Mr. Slocum? I've felt it in the air this long time past. D'you think I've not seen their ugly looks and the grudgin' way they worked? Well, Annie? David, I--  Wait! Yes, sir.

column1: D'you want anything nine; and myself thought maybe-- myself 'd go up on deck David to get a breath of fresh air, yet it 's too cold nine, and you had best stay below; yet there 's nothing to look at on deck-- but ice, and myself know-- ice cream ice ice!
column2: D'you want anything, Annie? I thought maybe--I'd go up on deck, David, to get a breath of fresh air. It's too cold, Annie. You'd best stay below. There's nothing to look at on deck--but ice. I know--ice, ice, ice!

column1: But nothing to see here folks down here but these walls, you can play the organ nine; and i hate the organ, and it puts me of mind of home, and i got it jest for ok you, and i know, and ah water; and clear water; and as far as myself can see!
column2: But there's nothing to see down here but these walls. You can play the organ, Annie. I hate the organ. It puts me in mind of home. I got it jest for you! I know. Ah, water! Clear water! As far as I can see!

column1: How good it looks following all these months of ice, and ah now myself must go up on deck also look at it David, best not to-day nine, best wait for per Day when the sun shines, yet but sun never shines of that dreadful place.
column2: How good it looks after all these months of ice! Ah, now I must go up on deck and look at it, David! Best not to-day, Annie. Best wait for a day when the sun shines. But the sun never shines in this terrible place.

column1: Best not to-day nine, and very well David; yet anne, and yes David, and me and Mr. locus has business to speak about-- ship 's always business; yet very well David, best not have her on the deck if they 's going ' to be any trouble, yet yes sir, and and trouble they 's going to be.
column2: Best not to-day, Annie. Very well, David. Annie! Yes, David. Me and Mr. Slocum has business to talk about--ship's business. Very well, David. Best not have her on deck if they's goin' to be any trouble. Yes, sir. And trouble they's going to be.

column1: I feel it of my bones, and got your'n; yes mister; not that our own serves will have to use 'em-- not assuming that I are awareness of their breed of dog-- jest to frighten 'em up a bit.
column2: I feel it in my bones. Got your'n? Yes, sir. Not that we'll have to use 'em--not if I know their breed of dog--jest to frighten 'em up a bit.

column1: I ai n't never been forced to use one it also trouble myself have had by land also by sea s'long as myself kin remember also will have till my dying ' day I reckon; then you ai not going '-- to turn come back, as turn back, as mr. locus did you ever heard o ' me pointing ' s'uth for home along only a meanly four hundred barrel inside ill in the hold?
column2: I ain't never been forced to use one yit; and trouble I've had by land and by sea s'long as I kin remember, and will have till my dyin' day, I reckon. Then you ain't goin'--to turn back? Turn back! Mr. Slocum, did you ever hear o' me pointin' s'uth for home with only a measly four hundred barrel of ile in the hold?

column1: God, yet what smasher; yet ulm; and i said God; and what smasher; as ah; as do you know this I have to repeat everything to you nowadays, and what, this myself have to repeat---- Yes myself heard, myself 'm i 'm sorry, yet myself become absorbed; inside all but me.
column2: God! What beauty! Umm? I said: God! What beauty! Aha! Do you know that I have to repeat everything to you nowadays? What? That I have to repeat----  Yes; I heard. I'm sorry. I get absorbed. In all but me.

column1: My dear your song was helping me like anything to take mood, that paper 's very deuce-- to pay between historical and natural, which wants the natural; ulm; wish I thought that, as modern taste, and history may go hang they 're everyone for tuppence-coloured sentiment nowadays.
column2: My dear, your song was helping me like anything to get the mood. This paper is the very deuce--to balance between the historical and the natural. Who wants the natural? Umm! Wish I thought that! Modern taste! History may go hang; they're all for tuppence-coloured sentiment nowadays.

column1: Is the Spring sentiment, and i beg your pardon my dear myself did not catch, and beauty beauty; that 's what I 'm i 'm trying to tell you here; and the Orpheus legend symbolized to this day call inside Beauty, and dash it!
column2: Is the Spring sentiment? I beg your pardon, my dear; I didn't catch. Beauty, beauty! That's what I'm, trying to say here. The Orpheus legend symbolizes to this day the call of Beauty! Dash it!

column1: I get so sleepy I wish you had tell them to make after-dinner coffee twice as strong; i will; and how does this strike you?
